questions.title: Passage Ⅰ
questions.article: The termite Reticulitermes flavipes consumes wood and bark. A study examined whether the consumption of wood or bark mulch by R. flavipes varies with the type of mulch or the age of the mulch. Separate portion of each of 5 types of mulch were aged (allowed to decay) for 1, 24, and 48 weeks. Then, 2 g of each type of 1-week-old mulch were put into a box, 2 g of each type of 24-week-old mulch were put into a second box, and 2 g of each type of 48-week-old mulch were put into a third box. Next, 1 g of R. flavipes was added to each box. After 15 days, the mass of mulch consumed, in milligrams (mg), was determined for each type and age of mulch (see figure).
questions.question: 1. Of the  following  combinations  of  type of  mulch and mulch age, which combination resulted in the greatest mass of mulch consumed by R. flavipes?

choices.A: type of mulch: oak               mulch age: 24 weeks
choices.B: type of mulch: pine bark     mulch age: 24 weeks
choices.C: type of mulch: oak               mulch age: 48 weeks
choices.D: type of mulch: pine bark     mulch age: 48 weeks

questions.title: Passage Ⅰ
questions.article: The termite Reticulitermes flavipes consumes wood and bark. A study examined whether the consumption of wood or bark mulch by R. flavipes varies with the type of mulch or the age of the mulch. Separate portion of each of 5 types of mulch were aged (allowed to decay) for 1, 24, and 48 weeks. Then, 2 g of each type of 1-week-old mulch were put into a box, 2 g of each type of 24-week-old mulch were put into a second box, and 2 g of each type of 48-week-old mulch were put into a third box. Next, 1 g of R. flavipes was added to each box. After 15 days, the mass of mulch consumed, in milligrams (mg), was determined for each type and age of mulch (see figure).
questions.question: 2. Which of the following statements about the effect of  mulch age on the consumption  of mulch by R. flavipes is consistent with the figure? As mulch age increased from 1 week through 48 weeks, the mass of mulch con­sumed by R. flavipes:

choices.A: decreased  for all 5 types of mulch.
choices.B: increased for all 5 types of  mulch.
choices.C: initially decreased for all 5 types of mulch, but then increased for some of the 5 types of mulch.
choices.D: initially increased for all 5 types of mulch, but then decreased for some of the 5 types of mulch.

questions.title: Passage Ⅰ
questions.article: The termite Reticulitermes flavipes consumes wood and bark. A study examined whether the consumption of wood or bark mulch by R. flavipes varies with the type of mulch or the age of the mulch. Separate portion of each of 5 types of mulch were aged (allowed to decay) for 1, 24, and 48 weeks. Then, 2 g of each type of 1-week-old mulch were put into a box, 2 g of each type of 24-week-old mulch were put into a second box, and 2 g of each type of 48-week-old mulch were put into a third box. Next, 1 g of R. flavipes was added to each box. After 15 days, the mass of mulch consumed, in milligrams (mg), was determined for each type and age of mulch (see figure).
questions.question: 3. Based on the passage, would R. flavipes be classified as an autotroph or as a detritivore, and why?

choices.A: Autotroph, because R. flavipes produces its own energy without consuming organic material.
choices.B: Autotroph, because R. flavipes obtains its energy by consuming decaying organic material.
choices.C: Detritivore, because R. flavipes produces its own energy without consuming organic material.
choices.D: Detritivore, because R. flavipes obtains its energy by consuming decaying organic material.

questions.title: Passage Ⅰ
questions.article: The termite Reticulitermes flavipes consumes wood and bark. A study examined whether the consumption of wood or bark mulch by R. flavipes varies with the type of mulch or the age of the mulch. Separate portion of each of 5 types of mulch were aged (allowed to decay) for 1, 24, and 48 weeks. Then, 2 g of each type of 1-week-old mulch were put into a box, 2 g of each type of 24-week-old mulch were put into a second box, and 2 g of each type of 48-week-old mulch were put into a third box. Next, 1 g of R. flavipes was added to each box. After 15 days, the mass of mulch consumed, in milligrams (mg), was determined for each type and age of mulch (see figure).
questions.question: 4. Based on the passage, is the primary food source of R. flavipes more likely cellulose or cholesterol?

choices.A: Cellulose; R. flavipes consumes the cell mem­branes of animal cells, and the cell membranes of animal cells contain cellulose.
choices.B: Cellulose; R. flavipes consumes the cell walls of plant cells, and the cell walls of plant cells consist primarily of cellulose.
choices.C: Cholesterol; R. flavipes consumes the cell membranes of animal cells, and the cell membranes of animal cells contain cholesterol.
choices.D: Cholesterol; R. flavipes consumes the cell walls of plant cells, and the cell walls of plant cells consist primarily of cholesterol.

questions.title: Passage Ⅰ

questions.question: 5. Which of the following statements comparing the consumption by R. flavipes of 1-week-old oak mulch, 24-week-old oak mulch, and 48-week-old oak mulch is supported by the figure?

choices.A: More 1-week-old mulch was consumed than 24-week-old mulch, and more 24-week-old mulch was consumed than 48-week-old mulch.
choices.B: Less 1-week-old mulch was consumed than 24-week-old mulch, and less 24-week-old mulch was consumed than 48-week-old mulch.
choices.C: More 1-week-old mulch was consumed than 24-week-old mulch, and less 24-week-old mulch was consumed than 48-week-old mulch.
choices.D: Less 1-week-old mulch was consumed than 24-week-old mulch, and more 24-week-old mulch was consumed than 48-week-old mulch.

questions.question: 6. What mass, in grams (NOT milligrams), of the 48-week-old oak bark mulch was consumed by R. flavipes?

questions.title: Passage II
questions.article:
Samples of Species C bacteria must often be transported from the areas in which they are collected. During transport, the samples are typically packed in ice to keep them alive. However, ice is not always available where the samples are collected.

Scientists studied how lyophilization (a freeze-drying process that doesn't require ice) followed by incubation affects the survival of 2 strains (Strain E and Strain V2) of species C bacteria.

Experiment 1
The scientists placed a 100 uL (1 μL=10-3 mL) sample of a nutrient medium containing 4 × 106 Strain E elementary bodies into each of 8 sterile test tubes. An elementary body is the infective form of Species C. The sample in each of the tubes was then lyophilized, and each tube was sealed. Two of the tubes were incubated at 4°C, 2 were incubated at 20°C, 2 were incubated. at 30°C, and 2 were incubated at 37°C.

One week after the start of incubation, the percent survival (the percent of the elementary bodies that survived) was determined for the sample in 1 of the 2 tubes at each temperature. Then, 1 month after the start of incubation, the percent survival was determined for the sample in the remaining tube at each temperature. The results are shown in Table 1.


Experiment 2
The scientists repeated Experiment 1, except with Strain V2 instead of Strain E. The results are shown in Table 2.
questions.question: 7. Which of the following statements describes a difference between Experiment 1 and Experiment 2 ?

choices.A: A different incubation temperature was tested in Experiment 1 than in Experiment 2.
choices.B: A different strain of Species C was tested in Experiment 1 than in Experiment 2.
choices.C: Samples in Experiment 1 were lyophilized before being transported, whereas samples in Experi­ment 2 were transported on ice.
choices.D: Samples in Experiment 1 were incubated for 1 week before being transported, whereas samples in Experi­ment 2 were incubated for 1 month before being transported.

questions.title: Passage II
questions.article:

Experiment 1
The scientists placed a 100 uL (1 μL=10-3 mL) sample of a nutrient medium containing 4 × 106 Strain E elementary bodies into each of 8 sterile test tubes. An elementary body is the infective form of Species C. The sample in each of the tubes was then lyophilized, and each tube was sealed. Two of the tubes were incubated at 4°C, 2 were incubated at 20°C, 2 were incubated. at 30°C, and 2 were incubated at 37°C.

One week after the start of incubation, the percent survival (the percent of the elementary bodies that survived) was determined for the sample in 1 of the 2 tubes at each temperature. Then, 1 month after the start of incubation, the percent survival was determined for the sample in the remaining tube at each temperature. The results are shown in Table 1.


Experiment 2
The scientists repeated Experiment 1, except with Strain V2 instead of Strain E. The results are shown in Table 2.
questions.question: 8. Suppose that in Experiment 2 the scientists had determined the percent survival for a sample incubated at 25°C for 1 week. The percent survival of the Strain V2 elementary bodies in the sample would most likely have been:

choices.B: between 2% and 29%.
choices.C: between 29% and 59%.
choices.D: greater than 59%.

questions.question: 9. At which 2 temperature was the percent survival of Strain V2 elementary bodies less for the longer incubation time than for the shorter incubation time?

questions.question: 10. Which of the following questions was NOT addressed by the experiments?

choices.A: Does incubation time affect the percent survival of Strain E and Strain V2 elementary bodies after lyophilization?
choices.B: Does temperature affect the percent survival of Strain E and Strain V2 elementary bodies after lyophilization?
choices.C: Does the number of Strain E or Strain V2 elementary bodies present in a sample before lyophilization affect their percent survival?
choices.D: Do Strain E elementary bodies have greater percent survival than Strain V2 elementary bodies after lyophilization and incubation?

questions.question: 11. One week after the start of incubation, which of the 4 samples of Strain V2 elementary bodies would have been least likely to infect another organism that came into contact with the samples?

choices.A: The sample that had been incubated at 4° C
choices.B: The sample that had been incubated at 10° C
choices.C: The sample that had been incubated at 20° C
choices.D: The sample that had been incubated at 37° C

questions.title: Passage II
questions.article:

Experiment 2

questions.question: 12. Suppose that a scientist wants to transport a lyophilized sample of Strain E elementary bodies. Based on the results of Experiment 1, which of the following combinations of temperature and transportation time would most likely ensure the greatest percent survival of the elementary bodies?

choices.A: 4°C and 1 week
choices.B: 4°C and 1 month
choices.C: 20°C and 1 week
choices.D: 20°C and 1 month

questions.question: 13. Consider the rating system in the table below for the percent survival of elementary bodies after lyophilization.Based on this table, what is the total number of tubes in Experiment 1 that contained samples having a poor percent survival?

questions.title: Passage Ⅲ
questions.article:
When an object is submerged in a fluid, the object dis­places a volume of fluid equal to the object's submerged volume. The fluid exerts an upward buoyant force on the object that is equal in magnitude to the weight of the dis­placed fluid. The object floats if the buoyant force equals the object's weight.

A group of students conducted 2 studies on buoyant forces using 3 fluids一water, Fluid A, and Fluid B一having densities of 1.0 g/cm3, 1.25 g/cm3, and 1.50 g/cm3, respectively.

Study 1
The students placed a 10 cm long cylinder in a con­tainer of water and measured the length o f the portion of the cylinder that was submerged. They then repeated this procedure with a container of Fluid A and o container of Fluid B (see Figure 1).


Study 2
The students placed a stone—either Stone X, Stone Y, or Stone Z—in a net that was tied to a spring balance. They recorded the force measured by the balance as the stone's weight, W. They then submerged the stone in water and again recorded the force measured by the balance (see Figure 2).


The students calculated the buoyant force on the stone in water as W minus the force that was measured when the stone was submerged. They repeated this procedure to test all 3 stones in all 3 fluids. Table 1 lists each stone's volume, in cm3, and W, in newtons (N), as well as the buoyant force, in N, on each stone in the fluid.
questions.question: 14. Bused on the results of Study 2, as the density of the fluid in which Stone X was submerged increased, the buoyant force on Stone X:

choices.A: decreased only.
choices.B: increased only.
choices.C: decreased and then increased.
choices.D: varied with no general trend.

The students calculated the buoyant force on the stone in water as W minus the force that was measured when the stone was submerged. They repeated this procedure to test all 3 stones in all 3 fluids. Table 1 lists each stone's volume, in cm3, and W, in newtons (N), as well as the buoyant force, in N, on each stone in the fluid.
questions.question: 15. Based on the results of Study 2, for Stone Y, what was the difference between the buoyant  force in  Fluid A and the buoyant force in Fluid B?

questions.question: 16. Suppose the students decide to study whether a cylin­der's volume determines the submerged length of the cylinder in a given fluid. Which of  the  following  procedural changes should the students make to Study 1? The students should test:

choices.A: a single cylinder with multiple fluids; the fluids should each have the same density as the cylinder.
choices.B: a single cylinder with multiple fluids; the fluids should have different densities.
choices.C: multiple cylinders with a single fluid; the cylinders should have different volumes but the  same density.
choices.D: multiple cylinders with a single fluid; the cylinders should  have  different   weights   but   the   same volume.

questions.question: 17. In Study 1, did the cylinder displace  a greater  volume of water or a greater volume of Fluid A ?

choices.A: Water, because the cylinder's submerged length was greater in water than in Fluid A.
choices.B: Water, because the cylinder's submerged length was greater in Fluid A than in water.
choices.C: Fluid A, because the cylinder's submerged length was greater in water than in Fluid A.
choices.D: Fluid A, because the cylinder's submerged length was greater in Fluid A than in water.

questions.question: 18. Suppose that in Study 1 the students had placed the cylinder in a container of fluid having a density of 1.6 g/cm³. The submerged length of the cylinder would most likely have been:

choices.A: less than 4.9 cm.
choices.B: between 4.9 cm and 5.9 cm.
choices.C: between 5.9 cm and 7.4 cm.
choices.D: greater than 7.4 cm.

questions.article:

Study 2

questions.question: 19. Suppose that in Study 2 the students had tested a stone having the same weight as Stone Z but a larger volume than Stone Z. Which of  the  following statements  about the  buoyant force on  this  submerged stone would be correct? The buoyant force on this stone in:

choices.A: water would have been less than 0.94 N.
choices.B: Fluid A would have been less than 1.18 N.
choices.C: Fluid B would have been greater than 1.41 N.
choices.D: water would have been greater than the buoyant force on this stone in Fluid A.

questions.title: Passage Ⅲ
questions.article:

The fluid exerts an upward buoyant force on the object that is equal in magnitude to the weight of the dis­placed fluid. The object floats if the buoyant force equals the object's weight.

A group of students conducted 2 studies on buoyant forces using 3 fluids一water, Fluid A, and Fluid B一having densities of 1.0 g/cm3, 1.25 g/cm3, and 1.50 g/cm3, respectively.

Study 1
The students placed a 10 cm long cylinder in a con­tainer of water and measured the length o f the portion of the cylinder that was submerged. They then repeated this procedure with a container of Fluid A and o container of Fluid B (see Figure 1).


Study 2
The students placed a stone—either Stone X, Stone Y, or Stone Z—in a net that was tied to a spring balance. They recorded the force measured by the balance as the stone's weight, W. They then submerged the stone in water and again recorded the force measured by the balance (see Figure 2).


The students calculated the buoyant force on the stone in water as W minus the force that was measured when the stone was submerged. They repeated this procedure to test all 3 stones in all 3 fluids. Table 1 lists each stone's volume, in cm3, and W, in newtons (N), as well as the buoyant force, in N, on each stone in the fluid.
questions.question: 20. Assume that Atlantic Ocean water has a density of 1.01 g/cm3 and that  Pacific  Ocean  water  has  a  density of 1.0 3 g/cm3. Based on the results of  Study 1, in which ocean would  a  given  iceberg more  likely have the greater submerged volume?

choices.A: The Atlantic Ocean, because the results of Study 1 indicate that submerged volume increases as fluid density decreases.
choices.B: The Atlantic Ocean, because the results of Study 1 indicate that submerged volume decreases as fluid density decreases.
choices.C: The Pacific Ocean, because the results of Study 1 indicate that submerged volume increases as fluid density decreases.
choices.D: The Pacific Ocean, because the results of Study 1 indicate that submerged volume decreases as fluid density decreases.

questions.title: Passage Ⅳ
questions.article:
Chemical reaction that release heat areexothermic reactions. The amount of heat released depends on the number of moles of reactants consumed in the reaction. A mole of any substance is 6 × 1023 molecules or formula units of the substance.

When sodium hypochlorite (NaCIO) and sodium iodide (NaI) are dissolved in acidic H2O, an exothermic reaction occurs

NaCIO + NaI → products + heat

Students did an experiment to study this reaction.

Experiment
In each of 8 trails, the students performed Steps 1-5:

1. A known volume of a 0.2 mole/L aqueous NaCIO solu­tion was poured into a foam coffee cup. A lid was placed on the cup.

2. A thermometer was placed into the solution through a hole in the lid. The solution's initial temperature, Ti, of 22.0° C was recorded.

3. The lid was lifted, and a known volume of a 0.2 mole/L aqueous NaI solution, also at a Ti of 22.0°C, was poured into the cup. The lid was put back on the cup, and the solution was swirled.

4. The solution's final (maximum) temperature, Tf was measured.

5. The change in temperature, △T, was calculated :

△T= Tf - Ti

The data for each trail are shown in Table 1.


The students plotted △T versus the volume of NaCIO solution for each trail (see Figure 1).


Then they identified the trial for which △T had its greatest value. The ratio of volume of the NaCIO solution to the volume of the NaI solution for this trial is the mole ratio for the reaction.
questions.question: 21. If a trial had been performed with 60 mL of NaCIO solution and 40 mL of NaI solution, Tf would most likely have been:

choices.A: less than 25.5°C.
choices.B: between 25.5°C and 29.0°C.
choices.C: between 29.0°C and 31.7°C.
choices.D: greater than 31.7°C.

questions.question: 22. Before the experiment, a student predicted that △T for Trial 2 would be greater than △T for Trial 6. Do the results shown in Table 1 support this prediction?

choices.A: No; △T for Trial 2 was 5.1°C less than △T for Trial 6.
choices.B: No; △T for Trial 2 was 8.6°C less than △T for Trial 6.
choices.C: Yes; △T for Trial 2 was 5.1°C greater than △T for Trial 6.
choices.D: Yes; △T for Trial 2 was 8.6°C greater than △T for Trial 6.

questions.question: 23. In each trial, the total volume of solution poured into the cup was:

choices.A: 25mL.

questions.question: 26. Which of the following statements best explains why △T was 0.0°C for Trial 8? The volume of solution added was 0 mL for one of the:

choices.A: products, NaCIO, so no reaction had occurred.

choices.C: reactants, NaCIO, so no reaction had occurred.
choices.D: reactants, NaI, so no reaction had occurred.

questions.question: 27. Suppose that the reaction studied had been endothermic. As the endothermic reaction progressed, would the solution temperature more likely have decreased or increased?

choices.A: Decreased, because the reaction would have released heat.
choices.B: Decreased, because the reaction would have absorbed heat.
choices.C: Increased, because the reaction would have released heat.
choices.D: Increased, because the reaction would have absorbed heat.

questions.title: Passage Ⅴ
questions.article:
When rocks are melted at very high temperatures beneath Earth's surface, magma (molten rock) is formed. The gases CO2, and H2O can dissolve in magma. Figure 1 shows, for 4 different magmas (leucitite, basanite, rhyolite, and tholeiitic basalt), how the solubility of CO2 in the magma at 1,150°C varies with pressure (in megapascals MPa).


Figure 2 shows, at 3 different pressures, how the solubility of CO2 in rhyolite magma varies with temperature.


Figure 3 shows, at 4 different pressures, how the solubility of CO2, in rhyolite magma at 750°C varies with the weight percent of H2O in the magma.
questions.question: 28. According to Figure 2, at 300 MPa, the solubility of CO2 in rhyolite magma is closest to 2,000 ppmw at which of the following temperatures?

questions.question: 29. Based on Figure 3, at 750°C and 350 MPa, rhyolite magma having a solubility of CO2, equal to 1, 250 ppmw would most likely have a weight percent of H2O that is:

choices.A: less than 2.0%.
choices.B: between 2.0% and 4.0%.
choices.C: between 4.0% and 6.0%.
choices.D: greater than 6.0%.

questions.title: Passage VI
questions.article:
When viewed from Earth, the other planets in the solar system usually appear to move prograde (eastward relative to the stars). Occasionally, however, each planet appears to briefly move retrograde (westward relative to the stars). For example, Figure 1 shows Mars's position relative to the stars on 9 dates between July 24, 2005, and February 26, 2006.


Two hypotheses were proposed to explain why the planets occasionally appear to move retrograde.

Hypothesis 1
Earth is the solar system's central body, and the other bodies move around Earth in looped orbits. Each body (except Earth) has 2 circles associated with it: a deferent and an epicycle. Both circles rotate counterclockwise, and their combined motions result in a body following a looped orbit. In Figure 2, the left panel shows Mars's deferent and epicycle, and the right panel shows Mars's orbit.


As a body passes through a loop. the body's motion changes from prograde and back. The larger a body's deferent. the more loops in the body's orbit. and the more often that body passes through a loop.

Hypothesis 2
The Sun is the solar system's central body, and the planets move counterclockwise around the Sun in elliptical orbits. The larger a planet's orbit, the more time the planet takes to complete a revolution around the Sun. As a result, the line of sight from Earth to a given planet drifts over time. Figure 3 shows the orbits Earth and Mars, and the positions of Earth and Mars, on each of the 4 dates labeled in Figure 1. For each date, the line of sight from Earth to Mars is projected onto a view of the sky.

There are 2 rules for apparent retrograde motion:

• A planet with an orbit larger than Earth's appears to move retrograde whenever Earth passes between the Sun and that planet. The larger that planet's orbit, the more often a pass occurs.

• A planet with an orbit smaller than Earth's appears to move retrograde whenever that planet passes between the Sun and Earth. The smaller that planet's orbit, the more often a pass occurs.
questions.question: 34. Which of the following statements best describes a primary difference between the two hypotheses? Hypothesis 1 claims that all planets follow:

choices.A: looped orbits around Earth, whereas Hypothesis 2 claims that all planets follow elliptical orbits around the Sun.
choices.B: looped orbits around Earth, whereas Hypothesis 2 claims that all planets follow elliptical orbits around Earth.
choices.C: elliptical orbits around the Sun, whereas Hypothesis 2 claims that all planets follow looped orbits around the Sun.
choices.D: elliptical orbits around the Sun, whereas Hypothesis 2 claims that all planets follow looped orbits around Earth.

questions.question: 35. Assume that Figures 2 and 3 are drawn to scale. Which of the figures, if either, implies that the distance between Earth and Mars varies with time?

choices.A: Figure 2 only
choices.B: Figure 3 only
choices.C: Both Figure 2 and Figure 3
choices.D: Neither Figure 2 nor Figure 3

questions.question: 36. Consider both the interval of time represented in Figures 1 and 3 and the reason that, according to Hypothesis 2, the line of sight from Earth to Mars drifts over time. Is the top portion of Figure 3 consistent with that reason?

choices.A: Yes; Earth is shown as having the smaller orbit and as having completed a greater percentage of its revolution around the Sun than is Mars.
choices.B: Yes; Earth is shown as having the larger orbit and as having completed a greater percentage of its revolution around the Sun than is Mars.
choices.C: No; Earth is shown as having the smaller orbit and as having completed a greater percentage of its revolution around the Sun than is Mars.
choices.D: No; Earth is shown as having the larger orbit and as having completed a greater percentage of its revolution around the Sun than is Mars.

questions.question: 37. Based on Figure 1, as viewed from Earth, for approximately how many days between July 2005 and February 2006 did Mars move retrograde?

When viewed from Earth, the other planets in the solar system usually appear to move prograde (eastward relative to the stars). Occasionally, however, each planet appears to briefly move retrograde (westward relative to the stars). For example, Figure 1 shows Mars's position relative to the stars on 9 dates between July 24, 2005, and February 26, 2006.


Two hypotheses were proposed to explain why the planets occasionally appear to move retrograde.

Hypothesis 1
Earth is the solar system's central body, and the other bodies move around Earth in looped orbits. Each body (except Earth) has 2 circles associated with it: a deferent and an epicycle. Both circles rotate counterclockwise, and their combined motions result in a body following a looped orbit. In Figure 2, the left panel shows Mars's deferent and epicycle, and the right panel shows Mars's orbit.


As a body passes through a loop. the body's motion changes from prograde and back. The larger a body's deferent. the more loops in the body's orbit. and the more often that body passes through a loop.

Hypothesis 2
The Sun is the solar system's central body, and the planets move counterclockwise around the Sun in elliptical orbits. The larger a planet's orbit, the more time the planet takes to complete a revolution around the Sun. As a result, the line of sight from Earth to a given planet drifts over time. Figure 3 shows the orbits Earth and Mars, and the positions of Earth and Mars, on each of the 4 dates labeled in Figure 1. For each date, the line of sight from Earth to Mars is projected onto a view of the sky.

There are 2 rules for apparent retrograde motion:

• A planet with an orbit larger than Earth's appears to move retrograde whenever Earth passes between the Sun and that planet. The larger that planet's orbit, the more often a pass occurs.

• A planet with an orbit smaller than Earth's appears to move retrograde whenever that planet passes between the Sun and Earth. The smaller that planet's orbit, the more often a pass occurs.
questions.question: 38. A supporter of Hypothesis 1 and a supporter of Hypothesis 2 would both be likely to agree with which of the following statements? When viewed from Earth, if a planet appears to be moving prograde, that planet is actually moving:

choices.A: clockwise around Earth.
choices.B: clockwise around the central body in the solar system.
choices.C: counterclockwise around the Sun.
choices.D: counterclockwise around the central body in the solar system.

questions.title: Passage VI

• A planet with an orbit smaller than Earth's appears to move retrograde whenever that planet passes between the Sun and Earth. The smaller that planet's orbit, the more often a pass occurs.
questions.question: 39. Based on Figures 1 and 3, if Hypothesis 2 is correct, which of the following figures most likely shows thepositions of Earth and Mars on November 7, 2005?

questions.title: Passage VI
questions.article:

questions.question: 40. Can Hypothesis 2 explain why Venus occasionally appears to move retrograde?

choices.A: Yes; Hypothesis 2 accounts for the motion of planets that are closer to the Sun than Earth is.
choices.B: Yes; Hypothesis 2 accounts for the motion of planets that are farther from the Sun than Earth is.
choices.C: No; Hypothesis 2 does not account for the motion of planets that are closer to the Sun than Earth is.
choices.D: No; Hypothesis 2 does not account for the motion of planets that are farther from to the Sun than Earth is.
